TEXT:
Chief Complaint:
   24 Hour Events:
   - CXR with diffuse right sided pulmonary vascular congestion and left
   lower lobe opacity/effusion/atelectasis
   - Underwent DCCV and converted to NSR with atrial tach
   - Got 5mg lopressor to control atrial tach
   - Was continued on dopa 8mcg/min without ability to wean off
   - Gave fluid challenge for hypotension/low UOP with resultant continued
   decrease in UOP from 15->8mL/hr so tried lasix 40mg IV this am.
   Allergies:
   Last dose of Antibiotics:
   Infusions:
   Heparin Sodium - 900 units/hour
   Dopamine - 8 mcg/Kg/min
   Other ICU medications:
   Metoprolol - [**2154-3-12**] 08:00 PM
   Furosemide (Lasix) - [**2154-3-13**] 06:21 AM
   Other medications:
   Changes to medical and family history:
   Review of systems is unchanged from admission except as noted below
   Review of systems:

   PaO2 / FiO2: 282
   Physical Examination
   Gen: WDWN middle aged female in NAD. Oriented x3. Mood, affect
   appropriate.
   HEENT: NCAT. Sclera anicteric. PERRL, EOMI. Conjunctiva were pink, no
   pallor or cyanosis of the oral mucosa. No xanthalesma.
   Neck: Supple with no JVD.
   CV: PMI located in 5th intercostal space, midclavicular line. Irreg
   irreg, normal S1, S2. 3/6 systolic murmur best heard at apex. No
   thrills, lifts. No S3 or S4.
   Chest: Wheezing on inspiration and expiration bilaterally. No rales.
   Abd: Soft, NTND. No HSM or tenderness. Abd aorta not enlarged by
   palpation. No abdominial bruits.
   Ext: Bilateral pitting edema. No femoral bruits.
   Skin: No stasis dermatitis, ulcers, scars, or xanthomas.

   Other labs: PT / PTT / INR:14.3/150.0/1.2, CK / CKMB /
   Troponin-T:2159/273/14.93, Differential-Neuts:94.8 %, Lymph:3.0 %,
   Mono:2.0 %, Eos:0.1 %, Lactic Acid:1.1 mmol/L, Ca++:7.9 mg/dL, Mg++:2.7
   mg/dL, PO4:6.3 mg/dL
   Imaging: No previous images. There is enlargement of the cardiac
   silhouette
   with pulmonary vascular congestion. Extensive opacification at the left
   base
   could reflect merely atelectasis and pleural effusion. However, the
   possibility of a left lower lobe consolidation as described from the
   outside
   hospital can certainly not be excluded.
   Dual-channel pacemaker device is in place.
   Assessment and Plan
   80 yo woman with HTN HL CAD now s/p primary PCI to the mid-RCA for
   inferior STEMI.
   #. Inferior STEMI: now s/p primary PCI to the mid-RCA.
   - CK peaked at 3000
   - continue aspirin 325, clopidogrel 75
   - cont home simvastatin 80
   - hold carvedilol, lisinopril given hypotension
   - TTE today
   # Hypotension/shock: cardiogenic vs septic shock. wbc count elevated.
   no fever. ?h/o c diff +ve. no h/o fever or diarrhea. Lactate low. CXR
   consistent with pulm edema and/or PNA of LLL. Tried fluid boluses as
   thought cardiogenic shock may be preload dependent given RCA infarct
   but UOP did not increase and had to increase dopa so may consider this
   to be systolic failure and may need to diurese for better CO.
   - will attempt lasix drip to assist diuresis.
   - wean dopamine as tolerated
   - hold off on anti-HTNs
   - monitor fever curve and wbc count
   - Consider amio to keep in NSR for better forward flow with atrial
   kick.
   - Consider changing pacemaker settings to change to atrial pacing
   # ?C diff diarrhea: no symptoms. wbc count at osh was 15
   - hold off on abx
   - send stool if has diarrhea
   #. Afib: new onset afib now s/p DCCV for hypotension
   - continue IV heparin
   - BB for rate control
   # CHF:
   - echo today
   - hold home dose lasix, lisinopril as pt hypotensive
   # HTN: hold amlodipine, BB, ACE as pt hypotensive
   #. COPD: cont home combivent
   #. Hyperparathyroidism: cont sensipar
   #. FEN: Replete lytes prn, cardiac diet
   #. Access:  PIV plus fem. Line placed at OSH [**2154-3-12**]
   #. PPx:  Sc heparin, bowel regimen prn
   #. Emergency contact:
   #. Code:  Presumed full
   #. Dispo: Pending resolution of above

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 80-year-old woman with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and coronary artery disease (CAD) who presented with inferior STEMI and was treated with primary PCI to the mid-RCA. She has been admitted to the ICU for further management.

The patient's current condition is characterized by:

* Hypotension (BP: 92/51 mmHg) with decreased urine output (UOP: 8 mL/hr)
* Pulmonary vascular congestion and left lower lobe opacity/effusion/atelectasis on CXR
* Atrial tachycardia with conversion to sinus rhythm after DCCV
* Elevated white blood cell count (WBC: 20.5 K/uL)
* No fever
* Low lactate level
* No symptoms of diarrhea
* Possible C. difficile infection (WBC: 15 at OSH)

The patient is receiving the following medications:

* Dopamine 8 mcg/Kg/min
* Lopressor 5 mg
* Lasix 40 mg IV
* Heparin sodium 900 units/hour
* Metoprolol 8 mg PO
* Furosemide (Lasix) 40 mg IV

The patient's lab results show:

* Elevated troponin-T (14.93 ng/mL)
* Elevated CK (2159 U/L)
* Elevated CK-MB (273 U/L)
* Elevated lactate (1.1 mmol/L)
* Normal calcium (7.9 mg/dL), magnesium (2.7 mg/dL), and phosphorus (6.3 mg/dL) levels

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Cardiogenic shock due to hypotension and decreased UOP
* Pulmonary edema and/or pneumonia of the left lower lobe
* C. difficile infection
* Sepsis
* Atrial fibrillation
* Hypothyroidism
* Hyperparathyroidism
* Chronic kidney disease

Based on the patient's condition and lab results, the plan is to:

* Continue dopamine to support blood pressure
* Wean dopamine as tolerated
* Attempt lasix drip to assist diuresis
* Hold off on anti-HTNs
* Monitor fever curve and WBC count
* Consider amiodarone to keep in NSR for better forward flow with atrial kick
* Consider changing pacemaker settings to change to atrial pacing
* Send stool if patient develops diarrhea
* Replete lytes prn and provide cardiac diet

Based on the provided medical note, the patient is an 80-year-old woman with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, coronary artery disease, and hyperparathyroidism, who was admitted with an inferior ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) and underwent primary percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) to the mid-right coronary artery. 

The patient has developed several complications since admission, including:

1. Atrial fibrillation (Afib) with rapid ventricular response, which was treated with IV heparin and beta-blockers for rate control.
2. Hypotension, which is suspected to be cardiogenic or septic in origin, and is being managed with vasopressors and fluid challenges.
3. Pulmonary congestion and left lower lobe opacity/effusion/atelectasis, which may be due to atelectasis, pleural effusion, or left lower lobe consolidation.
4. Elevated white blood cell count, which may indicate infection, but the patient does not have fever or symptoms of infection.

The patient is being treated with various medications, including aspirin, clopidogrel, simvastatin, and heparin, and is being monitored for potential complications. 

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Cardiac arrhythmias, including atrial fibrillation, ventricular tachycardia, or ventricular fibrillation.
2. Pulmonary edema or respiratory failure due to cardiogenic or septic shock.
3. Infection, including Clostridioides difficile (C. diff) colitis, which is suspected based on the patient's elevated white blood cell count and previous history of C. diff positivity.
4. Kidney injury or acute kidney injury due to hypotension, sepsis, or other underlying conditions.
5. Electrolyte imbalances, including hyperkalemia, hypokalemia, or hypocalcemia, which may be due to medication or underlying conditions.
6. Gastrointestinal complications, including diarrhea, nausea, or vomiting, which may be related to C. diff infection or other underlying conditions.

Given the patient's complex medical condition and multiple potential complications, close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent further deterioration and ensure optimal outcomes.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 80-year-old woman with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and coronary artery disease (CAD) who presented with an inferior STEMI and underwent primary PCI to the mid-RCA. She has been admitted to the ICU for further management.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: She has diffuse right-sided pulmonary vascular congestion and left lower lobe opacity/effusion/atelectasis, which is consistent with pulmonary edema and possible left lower lobe consolidation.
* Cardiovascular: She has a dual-channel pacemaker device in place, and her cardiac rhythm is currently in sinus rhythm. She has a 3/6 systolic murmur at the apex, which may indicate mitral regurgitation.
* Hemodynamic: Her blood pressure is 92/51 mmHg, and her heart rate is 83 beats per minute. She has a fluid challenge with a resulting decrease in urine output, and she has been given lasix 40mg IV this morning.
* Laboratory results: Her WBC count is elevated at 20.5, and her troponin-T level is 14.93. Her creatinine level is 2.3 mg/dL, and her potassium level is 4.3 mEq/L.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Cardiogenic shock due to hypotension and decreased cardiac output
* Septic shock due to elevated WBC count and possibility of sepsis
* Pulmonary edema and respiratory failure due to cardiac and respiratory compromise
* Atrial fibrillation with risk of embolization and stroke
* Hypocalcemia and hypomagnesemia due to elevated troponin-T levels and possible cardiac damage
* Renal failure due to decreased urine output and elevated creatinine level
* Hyperkalemia due to elevated potassium level

The plan of care for the patient includes:

* Continuing aspirin and clopidogrel for antiplatelet therapy
* Holding carvedilol and lisinopril due to hypotension
* Monitoring for signs of sepsis and cardiac compromise
* Weaning off pressors and monitoring for signs of shock
* Holding off on antibiotics until further evaluation
* Sending stool for evaluation if diarrhea develops
* Continuing home simvastatin and combivent for lipid management and COPD treatment, respectively
* Repleting electrolytes as needed and monitoring for signs of cardiac damage.

Summary:

The patient is an 80-year-old woman with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and coronary artery disease who presented with an inferior STEMI and underwent primary PCI to the mid-RCA. She developed atrial fibrillation and was converted to normal sinus rhythm with DCCV. She was given lopressor to control atrial tachycardia and was continued on dopamine to maintain blood pressure. She was also given lasix to treat fluid overload and hypotension.

Current Condition:

The patient's condition is stable, with a blood pressure of 92/51 mmHg and a heart rate of 83 bpm. Her oxygen saturation is 97% on high-flow nebulization. Her lung fields are clear, and her abdomen is soft and non-tender. She has bilateral pitting edema and no femoral bruits.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiogenic shock: Given the patient's history of inferior STEMI and the presence of pulmonary vascular congestion on CXR, there is a risk of cardiogenic shock.
2. Sepsis: The patient's elevated white blood cell count and the presence of bilateral pitting edema may indicate sepsis.
3. Diabetic ketoacidosis: The patient's glucose level is 105 mg/dL, which is slightly elevated, and she may be at risk for developing diabetic ketoacidosis.
4. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's potassium level is 4.3 mEq/L, which is slightly low, and her magnesium level is 2.7 mg/dL, which is slightly low. She may be at risk for developing an electrolyte imbalance.
5. Pulmonary embolism: The patient's CXR shows evidence of pulmonary vascular congestion, which may indicate a pulmonary embolism.
6. Left lower lobe consolidation: The patient's CXR also shows evidence of opacification at the left base, which may indicate a left lower lobe consolidation.
7. Hypothyroidism: The patient's TSH level is not provided, but she may be at risk for developing hypothyroidism given her age and the presence of hyperparathyroidism.
8. Chronic kidney disease: The patient's creatinine level is 2.3 mg/dL, which is slightly elevated, and she may be at risk for developing chronic kidney disease.

Recommendations:

1. Continue monitoring the patient's blood pressure, heart rate, and oxygen saturation.
2. Continue treatment for cardiogenic shock and sepsis.
3. Monitor the patient's glucose level and adjust treatment as necessary.
4. Monitor the patient's electrolyte levels and adjust treatment as necessary.
5. Consider obtaining an echocardiogram to assess the patient's left ventricular function and mitral regurgitation.
6. Consider obtaining a CT scan to rule out a pulmonary embolism.
7. Consider obtaining a thyroid function test to assess the patient's thyroid status.
8. Consider obtaining a urinalysis to assess the patient's kidney function.

Summary:

The patient is an 80-year-old woman with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and coronary artery disease, who presented with an inferior ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) and was treated with primary percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) to the mid-right coronary artery. She has been admitted to the ICU for management of cardiogenic shock, atrial fibrillation, and possible Clostridioides difficile (C. diff) infection.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.2C, heart rate of 83 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 92/51 mmHg. Her respiratory rate is 35 breaths per minute, and her oxygen saturation is 97% on high-flow nasal oxygen. Her physical examination reveals bilateral pitting edema, wheezing on inspiration and expiration, and a systolic murmur at the apex.

Laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, troponin-T, and lactate, but normal glucose levels. Imaging studies reveal pulmonary vascular congestion and opacification at the left base, which may be due to atelectasis, pleural effusion, or left lower lobe consolidation.

Potential medical complications:

1. Cardiogenic shock: The patient's hypotension and low urine output may indicate cardiogenic shock, which could worsen if not managed promptly.
2. Atrial fibrillation: The patient's new-onset atrial fibrillation may increase her risk of stroke and heart failure if not managed with rate control and anticoagulation.
3. C. diff infection: The patient's elevated white blood cell count and lack of fever or diarrhea symptoms may indicate a C. diff infection, which could worsen if not treated promptly.
4. Pulmonary edema: The patient's CXR findings and laboratory results may indicate pulmonary edema, which could worsen if not managed with diuresis and oxygen therapy.
5. Heart failure: The patient's echocardiogram findings and laboratory results may indicate heart failure, which could worsen if not managed with diuretics and vasodilators.
6. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension may worsen if not managed with fluid resuscitation and vasopressors.
7. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count may be low, which could worsen if not managed with platelet transfusions.
8. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's laboratory results may indicate electrolyte imbalance, which could worsen if not managed with electrolyte replacement therapy.

Summary:

The patient is an 80-year-old woman with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and coronary artery disease (CAD) who presented with an inferior STEMI and underwent primary PCI to the mid-RCA. She is currently in the ICU due to hypotension, shock, and atrial tachycardia. Her vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.2C, heart rate of 83 bpm, and blood pressure of 92/51 mmHg. Her respiratory rate is 35 inspirations per minute, and her oxygen saturation is 97% on high-flow nasal oxygen. Her physical examination is notable for bilateral pitting edema, wheezing on inspiration and expiration, and a 3/6 systolic murmur at the apex.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, lactate level, and troponin-T level, consistent with cardiac injury and inflammation. Her electrolyte levels are within normal limits, except for a slightly elevated potassium level. Her imaging studies show enlargement of the cardiac silhouette with pulmonary vascular congestion and extensive opacification at the left base, which could reflect atelectasis and pleural effusion or a left lower lobe consolidation.

Potential medical complications:

1. Cardiogenic shock: The patient's hypotension and low urine output may be due to cardiogenic shock, which can worsen if not managed promptly.
2. Pulmonary edema: The patient's CXR shows diffuse right-sided pulmonary vascular congestion and left lower lobe opacity/effusion/atelectasis, which can worsen if not managed promptly.
3. Atrial fibrillation: The patient's new-onset atrial fibrillation may lead to decreased cardiac output and increased risk of embolic events if not managed promptly.
4. Infection: The patient's elevated white blood cell count and potential Clostridioides difficile infection may lead to sepsis and organ dysfunction if not managed promptly.
5. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's slightly elevated potassium level may lead to cardiac arrhythmias and other complications if not managed promptly.
6. Respiratory failure: The patient's wheezing and bilateral pitting edema may lead to respiratory failure if not managed promptly.

Plan:

1. Continue aspirin, clopidogrel, and simvastatin.
2. Hold carvedilol, lisinopril, and amlodipine due to hypotension.
3. Check echo and WMA after STEMI.
4. Wean off pressors as able.
5. Hold off on antibiotics until further evaluation.
6. Monitor fever curve and white blood cell count.
7. Consider amiodarone to keep the patient in sinus rhythm.
8. Replete electrolytes as needed.
9. Provide cardiac diet and bowel regimen as needed.

   inferior STEMI.
   #. MR: Has posterior pap muscle ischemia and severe MR but not a flail
   leaflet
   - Will attempt to get volume off with UF to decrease MR

   - CK peaked at 3000
   - continue aspirin 325, clopidogrel 75

   - TTE today

   - Cte IABP until no longer necessary
   - hold off on anti-HTNs

   - Continue dopa

   - cls renal today for possibility of UF for volume overload
   - add urine eos for ?hypersensitivity reaction
   # ?C diff diarrhea: no symptoms.

   - continue IV heparin
   - BB for rate control

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 80-year-old woman with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and coronary artery disease, who presented with inferior STEMI and underwent primary PCI to the mid-RCA. She is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation, with a diagnosis of posterior papillary muscle ischemia and severe mitral regurgitation.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.9C, heart rate of 70-83 bpm, and blood pressure of 99/37-135/47 mmHg. Her oxygen saturation is 97% on 40% FiO2. Her cardiac rhythm is paced.

The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation, which was converted to normal sinus rhythm with DCCV. She is currently receiving heparin, aspirin, clopidogrel, and simvastatin.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated troponin-T and CK levels, indicating myocardial infarction. Her creatinine level is elevated, and she has a history of hyperparathyroidism.

The patient's imaging studies show moderate-to-severe mitral regurgitation, with thickened mitral valve leaflets and posterior papillary muscle ischemia. Her left ventricular systolic function is low normal, with inferolateral hypokinesis.

The patient's clinical course is complicated by hypotension, which may be due to cardiogenic or septic shock. She has a history of C. difficile infection and is at risk for volume overload and acute kidney injury.

The patient's plan of care includes continued IABP support, diuresis to improve cardiac output, and consideration of mitral valve repair or replacement if her mitral regurgitation does not improve. She will also continue to receive anticoagulation therapy and antiplatelet agents.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Cardiogenic shock: due to severe mitral regurgitation and posterior papillary muscle ischemia, which may worsen if not treated promptly.
2. Acute kidney injury: due to volume overload, hypotension, and potential septic shock.
3. Respiratory failure: due to pulmonary edema and/or pneumonia.
4. Septic shock: due to potential sepsis and C. difficile infection.
5. Bleeding complications: due to anticoagulation therapy and IABP support.
6. Infection: due to prolonged intubation and potential sepsis.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust her treatment plan accordingly to prevent or manage these potential complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 58-inch tall individual with a chief complaint of ischemic posterior papillary muscle intubated, TEE, and IABP placed. The patient is receiving Heparin Sodium, Furosemide (Lasix), Dopamine, and other ICU medications. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.9C (98.4F), heart rate of 70-83 bpm, blood pressure of 99/37-135/47 mmHg, and respiratory rate of 12-35 inspirations per minute. The patient's oxygen saturation is 97%, and the heart rhythm is paced.

The patient's hemodynamic monitoring shows a central venous pressure of 16 mmHg, pulmonary artery pressure of 45/23 mmHg, and cardiac output of 4.7 L/min. The patient's mixed venous oxygen saturation is 59-62%, and the total fluid intake is 1,790 mL. The patient's blood products include a total output of 133 mL, with 23 mL of urine output.

The patient's laboratory results show an elevated troponin-T level of 14.93 ng/mL, a moderate anion gap metabolic acidosis, and a mild hyperkalemia. The patient's imaging studies reveal a dilated left atrium, moderate to severe mitral regurgitation, and mild aortic stenosis.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiac Tamponade: The patient's IABP placement and TEE examination may have caused a small amount of bleeding or hematoma in the pericardial space, which could lead to cardiac tamponade.
2. Mitral Regurgitation: The patient's moderate to severe mitral regurgitation could lead to volume overload, pulmonary edema, and decreased cardiac output.
3. Aortic Stenosis: The patient's mild aortic stenosis could lead to decreased cardiac output, angina, and syncope.
4. Pulmonary Edema: The patient's moderate to severe mitral regurgitation and mild aortic stenosis could lead to pulmonary edema and respiratory failure.
5. Sepsis: The patient's central venous catheter and arterial lines could lead to sepsis, which could be exacerbated by the patient's immunosuppressed state.
6. Renal Failure: The patient's hypotension, oliguria, and elevated creatinine level could lead to acute kidney injury or renal failure.
7. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory rate of 12-35 inspirations per minute and mild hypercapnia could lead to respiratory failure.
8. Cardiac Arrest: The patient's underlying cardiac disease, electrolyte imbalances, and medication use could lead to cardiac arrest.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs, hemodynamic status, and laboratory results closely.
2. Adjust the patient's medication regimen as necessary to manage the patient's symptoms and prevent complications.
3. Consider echocardiography or cardiac catheterization to further evaluate the patient's cardiac function and anatomy.
4. Monitor the patient's blood glucose levels and adjust the patient's insulin regimen as necessary to prevent hyperglycemia.
5. Consider stress ulcer prophylaxis and stress ulcer treatment as necessary.
6. Monitor the patient's fluid status and adjust the patient's fluid management plan as necessary to prevent fluid overload.
7. Consider vasopressor support to maintain the patient's blood pressure and cardiac output.
8. Consider mechanical ventilation to manage the patient's respiratory failure.
9. Consider dialysis to manage the patient's renal failure.
10. Consider cardiac arrest protocols to manage the patient's cardiac arrest.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a middle-aged female with a history of myocardial infarction (MI) and is currently in the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) for further management. The patient has been intubated and is receiving mechanical ventilation, with a tidal volume of 400-605 mL, peak inspiratory pressure of 15 cmH2O, and a fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 40%.

The patient's hemodynamic monitoring shows a central venous pressure (CVP) of 16 mmHg, pulmonary artery pressure (PAP) of 45/23 mmHg, and cardiac output (CO) of 4.7 L/min with a cardiac index (CI) of 3 L/min/m2. The mixed venous oxygen saturation is 59-62%.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated troponin-T levels (14.93 ng/mL), indicating ongoing myocardial damage. The complete blood count (CBC) shows a white blood cell count of 20.5 x 10^9/L, hemoglobin of 8.4 g/dL, and platelet count of 180 x 10^9/L.

The patient's imaging studies, including the transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE), show severe mitral regurgitation with thickened mitral valve leaflets, moderate aortic stenosis, and moderate pulmonary artery systolic hypertension.

The patient's medical complications include:

1. Myocardial infarction with ongoing damage and potential for further complications.
2. Mitral regurgitation with poor leaflet apposition, which may be due to ischemic papillary muscle dysfunction or possible partial flail of the mitral leaflet.
3. Moderate aortic stenosis, which may contribute to the patient's hemodynamic instability.
4. Moderate pulmonary artery systolic hypertension, which may exacerbate the patient's cardiovascular instability.
5. Bilateral pitting edema, which may indicate fluid overload and potential for further complications.

The patient's current medications include heparin sodium, furosemide, dopamine, and midazolam. The patient's lines include a 20-gauge peripheral line, a pulmonary artery catheter, and an intra-aortic balloon pump (IABP) line.

The patient's plan of care includes continued ICU care, with close monitoring of hemodynamics, oxygenation, and ventilation. The patient will also require further management of her cardiac and respiratory status, including possible adjustments to her medication regimen and potential interventions such as cardiac catheterization or surgical intervention.

Based on the provided physician's daily progress note, I summarize the patient's health progress in the ICU as follows:

The patient is an 80-year-old woman with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and coronary artery disease who presented with an inferior STEMI and underwent primary PCI to the mid-RCA. She has been experiencing hypotension and shock, with a peak CK level of 3000. Her current vital signs include a temperature of 36.9C, heart rate of 70 bpm, blood pressure of 99/37 mmHg, respiratory rate of 12 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 97%.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, lactate levels, and troponin-T levels. Her ECG shows a paced rhythm, and her chest X-ray reveals pulmonary edema and/or pneumonia of the left lower lobe.

The patient's physical examination reveals bilateral pitting edema, no jugular venous distension, and a normal aortic valve. Her echocardiogram shows left ventricular systolic dysfunction consistent with inferior infarction/ischemia, moderate to severe mitral regurgitation, and mild aortic stenosis.

The patient's plan of care includes continuing aspirin, clopidogrel, and simvastatin, holding carvedilol and lisinopril due to hypotension, and attempting to wean dopamine as tolerated. She will also receive lasix drip to assist diuresis and may require amiodarone to maintain normal sinus rhythm. The patient's antibiotic treatment will be delayed pending further evaluation of her stool and white blood cell count.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Cardiogenic shock: The patient's hypotension and shock may worsen if not managed promptly.
2. Sepsis: The patient's elevated white blood cell count and lactate levels may indicate the presence of sepsis.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient's pulmonary edema and/or pneumonia may lead to respiratory failure if not managed effectively.
4. Renal failure: The patient's elevated creatinine levels and potential for diuretic use may increase the risk of renal failure.
5. Infection: The patient's history of C. difficile and her current antibiotic treatment may increase the risk of infection.
6. Arrhythmias: The patient's paced rhythm and history of atrial fibrillation may increase the risk of arrhythmias.
7. Bleeding: The patient's use of anticoagulants and antiplatelet agents may increase the risk of bleeding.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical condition to prevent or manage these potential complications.

   aortic regurgitation is seen. The mitral valve leaflets are moderately

   ischemia. No mitral leaflet flail seen. Severely thickened aortic valve
   leaflets with moderate aortic stenosis. IABP seen in the descending
   aorta.
   TTE
   The left atrium is dilated. Left ventricular wall thicknesses and
   cavity size are normal. There is severe symmetric left ventricular
   hypertrophy. There is mild regional left ventricular systolic
   dysfunction with moderate to severe hypokinesis of the basal to mid
   inferior and inferolateral segments. The other segments have
   hyperdynamic function. The right ventricular cavity is mildly dilated
   with normal free wall contractility. The aortic valve leaflets are
   moderately thickened. The mitral valve leaflets are mildly thickened.
   There is partial mitral leaflet flail. Moderate to severe (3+) mitral
   regurgitation is seen. The tricuspid valve leaflets are mildly
   thickened. There is moderate pulmonary artery systolic hypertension.
   There is no pericardial effusion.
   IMPRESSION: Regional LV systolic dysfunction consistent with inferior
   infarction/ischemia. Moderate to severe mitral regurgitation with poor
   leaflet apposition. This may be due to ischemic papillary muscle
   dysfunction or possible partial flail of the mitral leaflet. At least
   mild aortic stenosis. Moderate pulmonary artery systolic hypertension.
   Assessment and Plan
   80 yo woman with HTN HL CAD now s/p primary PCI to the mid-RCA for
   inferior STEMI.
   #. MR: Has posterior pap muscle ischemia and severe MR but not a flail
   leaflet
   - Will attempt to get volume off with UF to decrease MR
   - Will continue IABP for better CO
   - Will continue to monitor and if gets worse may need MVR
   #. Inferior STEMI: now s/p primary PCI to the mid-RCA.
   - CK peaked at 3000
   - continue aspirin 325, clopidogrel 75
   - cont home simvastatin 80
   - hold carvedilol, lisinopril given hypotension
   - TTE today
   # Hypotension/shock: cardiogenic vs septic shock. wbc count elevated.
   no fever. ?h/o c diff +ve. no h/o fever or diarrhea. Lactate low. CXR
   consistent with pulm edema and/or PNA of LLL. Tried fluid boluses as
   thought cardiogenic shock may be preload dependent given RCA infarct
   but UOP did not increase and had to increase dopa so may consider this
   to be systolic failure and may need to diurese for better CO.
   - Cte IABP until no longer necessary
   - hold off on anti-HTNs
   - Consider amio to keep in NSR for better forward flow with atrial
   kick.
   - Continue dopa
   - Stop lasix today
   # ARF: Likely seoncdary to two dye loads as well as poor CO
   - cls renal today for possibility of UF for volume overload
   - add urine eos for ?hypersensitivity reaction
   # ?C diff diarrhea: no symptoms.
   - d/c precautions today
   #. Afib: new onset afib now s/p DCCV for hypotension
   - continue IV heparin
   - BB for rate control
   # HTN: hold amlodipine, BB, ACE as pt hypotensive
   #. COPD: cont home combivent
   #. Hyperparathyroidism: cont sensipar

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 80-year-old woman who was admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of acute myocardial infarction (AMI) and is currently undergoing treatment for her condition. The patient's condition has been stable, with no significant changes in her vital signs or laboratory results over the past 24 hours.

The patient's cardiac status is of particular concern, as she has been diagnosed with severe mitral regurgitation (MR) and moderate aortic stenosis. The patient's left ventricular systolic function is also compromised, with moderate to severe hypokinesis of the basal to mid-inferior and inferolateral segments.

The patient's respiratory status is also of concern, as she has been diagnosed with pulmonary edema and/or pneumonia of the left lower lobe (LLL). The patient's oxygen saturation is 97% on 40% FiO2, and her respiratory rate is 12 breaths per minute.

The patient's hemodynamic status is also of concern, as she has been diagnosed with cardiogenic shock and has required vasopressor support. The patient's blood pressure is 99/37 mmHg, and her central venous pressure (CVP) is 16 mmHg.

The patient's laboratory results are also of concern, as she has been diagnosed with acute kidney injury (AKI) and is requiring renal replacement therapy (RRT). The patient's serum creatinine level is 2.3 mg/dL, and her blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level is 21 mg/dL.

The patient's medication regimen is also of concern, as she is receiving multiple medications to manage her cardiac and respiratory status. The patient is receiving heparin, aspirin, clopidogrel, simvastatin, carvedilol, lisinopril, and metoprolol, among others.

In summary, the patient is an 80-year-old woman who is currently undergoing treatment for AMI and has been diagnosed with severe MR, moderate aortic stenosis, pulmonary edema, and AKI. The patient's cardiac, respiratory, and hemodynamic status are all of concern, and her medication regimen is complex and multifaceted.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 80-year-old woman with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and coronary artery disease who presented with an inferior STEMI and underwent primary PCI to the mid-RCA. The patient is currently in the ICU due to cardiogenic shock and hypotension.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 98.4F, heart rate of 70 bpm, and blood pressure of 99/37 mmHg. Her oxygen saturation is 97% on 40% FiO2.

The patient's cardiac rhythm is atrial-paced, and she has a severe symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with mild regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction consistent with inferior infarction/ischemia. The mitral valve leaflets are moderately thickened with moderate to severe mitral regurgitation, which may be due to ischemic papillary muscle dysfunction or possible partial flail of the mitral leaflet.

The patient's respiratory support includes mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 400-605 mL, positive end-expiratory pressure of 5 cmH2O, and fraction of inspired oxygen of 40%. Her arterial blood gas results show a pH of 7.37, partial pressure of carbon dioxide of 37 mmHg, and partial pressure of oxygen of 213 mmHg.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, lactate level, and troponin-T level, consistent with cardiac injury and inflammation. Her creatinine level is 2.0 mg/dL, and her potassium level is 4.6 mEq/L.

The patient's medications include aspirin, clopidogrel, simvastatin, and heparin, and she is receiving IV dopamine and furosemide infusions. She is also receiving prophylactic antibiotics and antifungal agents.

The patient's potential medical complications include:

1. Cardiogenic shock: The patient's cardiac function is compromised, and she may require further support with inotropes and vasopressors.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory support is currently adequate, but she may require further adjustments to her ventilator settings or consideration of extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) if her condition deteriorates.
3. Sepsis: The patient's elevated white blood cell count and lactate level suggest the possibility of sepsis, which may require further evaluation and treatment.
4. Renal failure: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, and she may require further evaluation and treatment for potential renal failure.
5. Hyperkalemia: The patient's potassium level is elevated, and she may require further evaluation and treatment for potential hyperkalemia.

In summary, the patient is a complex case with multiple medical issues, including cardiogenic shock, respiratory failure, sepsis, renal failure, and hyperkalemia. Further evaluation and treatment are necessary to address these issues and improve the patient's outcomes.

Based on the patient's progress note, the following information can be summarized:

The patient is an 80-year-old woman who was admitted with hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and coronary artery disease. She underwent primary PCI to the mid-RCA for inferior STEMI. She has posterior papillary muscle ischemia and severe mitral regurgitation, but not a flail leaflet. She has been intubated and sedated.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.2C, heart rate of 83 bpm, and blood pressure of 92/34 mmHg. Her respiratory support includes high-flow nasal oxygen and CPAP/PSV ventilation. Her laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, low hemoglobin, and elevated troponin levels.

The patient has several medical complications, including:

1. Acute kidney injury (AKI): likely secondary to contrast-induced nephropathy and poor cardiac output.
2. Hypotension/shock: cardiogenic vs septic shock, with elevated white blood cell count and low lactate levels.
3. Inferior STEMI: now s/p primary PCI to the mid-RCA.
4. Mitral regurgitation: severe MR with posterior papillary muscle ischemia.
5. Respiratory failure: with pulmonary edema and/or pneumonia of the left lower lobe.
6. Hyperparathyroidism: with elevated calcium levels.

The patient's plan includes:

1. Renal ultrasound to rule out hydronephrosis, masses, or stones.
2. CVVH for contrast-induced nephropathy.
3. Discontinuation of chlorothiazide.
4. Monitoring of cardiac output and blood pressure.
5. Consideration of diuresis for better cardiac output.
6. Continue IABP until no longer necessary.
7. Hold off on anti-hypertensives.
8. Consider amiodarone to keep in normal sinus rhythm for better forward flow with atrial kick.
9. Continue dopamine.
10. Stop lasix today.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Worsening of AKI.
2. Development of sepsis.
3. Cardiac arrhythmias.
4. Respiratory failure.
5. Pneumonia.
6. Hyperkalemia.
7. Hypocalcemia.
8. Hypertension.
9. Diabetic ketoacidosis.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical status to prevent or manage these potential complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 58-inch tall individual who was admitted to the ICU with a chief complaint of invasive ventilation, which was discontinued. The patient has a history of acute renal failure, acute myocardial infarction, and contrast-induced nephropathy. They were started on continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT) with a dialysis catheter placed on the 14th of March. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.2C, heart rate of 83 bpm, and blood pressure of 92/34 mmHg. Their oxygen saturation is 99% and they are receiving high-flow nasal oxygen. The patient's respiratory support includes a ventilator mode of CPAP/PSV, with a peak inspiratory pressure of 16 cmH2O and a positive end-expiratory pressure of 5 cmH2O.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 16.9 K/uL, hemoglobin of 7.2 g/dL, and platelet count of 140 K/uL. Their blood urea nitrogen is 118 mg/dL, creatinine is 3.8 mg/dL, and potassium is 4.4 mEq/L. The patient's troponin-T level is 14.93 ng/mL, indicating acute myocardial infarction.

Potential medical complications:

1. Renal failure: The patient's acute renal failure is likely to continue, and they may require further dialysis or other renal replacement therapies.
2. Myocardial infarction: The patient's acute myocardial infarction may lead to further cardiac complications, such as heart failure, arrhythmias, or cardiogenic shock.
3. Contrast-induced nephropathy: The patient's contrast-induced nephropathy may exacerbate their acute renal failure and require further management.
4. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may lead to further respiratory complications, such as ventilator-associated pneumonia or respiratory acidosis.
5. Infection: The patient's immunosuppressed state and presence of central lines and catheters may increase their risk of infection, such as sepsis or central line-associated bloodstream infection.
6. Hemodynamic instability: The patient's hemodynamic instability may lead to further cardiac complications, such as hypotension or cardiogenic shock.
7. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's electrolyte imbalance may lead to further cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias or cardiac arrest.
8. Fluid overload: The patient's fluid overload may lead to further respiratory complications, such as pulmonary edema or respiratory failure.

   Assessment and Plan
   80 yo woman with HTN HL CAD now s/p primary PCI to the mid-RCA for
   inferior STEMI.
   #. MR: Has posterior pap muscle ischemia and severe MR but not a flail
   leaflet
   - Will attempt to get volume off with UF to decrease MR
   - Will continue IABP for better CO
   - Will continue to monitor and if gets worse may need MVR
   #. Inferior STEMI: now s/p primary PCI to the mid-RCA.
   - CK peaked at 3000
   - continue aspirin 325, clopidogrel 75
   - cont home simvastatin 80
   - hold carvedilol, lisinopril given hypotension
   - TTE today
   # Hypotension/shock: cardiogenic vs septic shock. wbc count elevated.
   no fever. ?h/o c diff +ve. no h/o fever or diarrhea. Lactate low. CXR
   consistent with pulm edema and/or PNA of LLL. Tried fluid boluses as
   thought cardiogenic shock may be preload dependent given RCA infarct
   but UOP did not increase and had to increase dopa so may consider this
   to be systolic failure and may need to diurese for better CO. Renal saw
   and recommended UF. Intermittent v pacing resulting in disynchroinous
   IABP pulsation.
   - Cte IABP; will atempt weaning today.
   - hold off on anti-HTNs
   - Consider amio to keep in NSR for better forward flow with atrial
   kick.
   - Continue dopa
   - Continue UF
   - will ask EP to look at pacing paramenters
   # ARF: Likely seoncdary to two dye loads as well as poor CO
   - cls renal today for possibility of UF for volume overload
   - add urine eos for ?hypersensitivity reaction
   # ?C diff diarrhea: no symptoms.
   - d/c precautions today
   #. Afib: new onset afib now s/p DCCV for hypotension
   - continue IV heparin
   - BB for rate control
   # HTN: hold amlodipine, BB, ACE as pt hypotensive
   #. COPD: cont home combivent
   #. Hyperparathyroidism: cont sensipar
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:

Summary:

The patient is an 80-year-old woman with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and coronary artery disease (CAD) who presented with an inferior ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) and was treated with primary percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) to the mid-right coronary artery (RCA). She is currently intubated and mechanically ventilated in the intensive care unit (ICU) due to cardiogenic shock and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).

The patient's current condition is complicated by several factors, including:

1. Cardiogenic shock: The patient's blood pressure is low, and she is requiring vasopressors to maintain adequate perfusion.
2. Acute kidney injury (AKI): The patient's creatinine levels are elevated, and she is requiring dialysis.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated and mechanically ventilated due to ARDS.
4. Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure is low, and she is requiring vasopressors to maintain adequate perfusion.
5. Inferior STEMI: The patient has had a recent inferior STEMI and is at risk for further cardiac complications.
6. Possible septic shock: The patient's white blood cell count is elevated, and she has a history of Clostridioides difficile (C. diff) infection.

Potential medical complications:

1. Cardiac complications: The patient is at risk for further cardiac complications, including cardiac arrest, heart failure, and arrhythmias.
2. Respiratory complications: The patient is at risk for further respiratory complications, including respiratory failure and ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).
3. Renal complications: The patient is at risk for further renal complications, including acute kidney injury and chronic kidney disease.
4. Infectious complications: The patient is at risk for further infectious complications, including sepsis, pneumonia, and C. diff infection.
5. Hemodynamic instability: The patient is at risk for further hemodynamic instability, including hypotension and shock.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac status closely and adjust therapy as needed to prevent further cardiac complications.
2. Continue to provide respiratory support and monitor the patient's respiratory status closely to prevent further respiratory complications.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's renal status closely and adjust therapy as needed to prevent further renal complications.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's infectious status closely and adjust therapy as needed to prevent further infectious complications.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's hemodynamic status closely and adjust therapy as needed to prevent further hemodynamic instability.

Summary:

The patient is an 80-year-old woman who was admitted with hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and coronary artery disease. She underwent primary PCI for inferior STEMI and has been experiencing cardiogenic shock, hypotension, and acute renal failure. She is currently on invasive ventilation, dialysis, and has a central venous catheter. Her lab results show elevated troponin, creatinine, and potassium levels. She has a history of hyperparathyroidism and is taking Sensipar.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiogenic shock: The patient's cardiogenic shock is likely due to the inferior STEMI and may worsen if not treated promptly.
2. Acute renal failure: The patient's acute renal failure is likely secondary to contrast-induced nephropathy and may worsen if not treated with dialysis.
3. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension is likely due to cardiogenic shock and may worsen if not treated with vasopressors and fluid resuscitation.
4. Sepsis: The patient's elevated WBC count and lack of fever suggest possible sepsis, which may worsen if not treated promptly.
5. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen if not treated with mechanical ventilation and oxygen therapy.
6. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's history of C. difficile infection and lack of symptoms may suggest gastrointestinal bleeding, which may worsen if not treated promptly.
7. Hyperkalemia: The patient's elevated potassium levels may worsen if not treated with potassium-binding agents.
8. Metabolic acidosis: The patient's elevated lactate levels may suggest metabolic acidosis, which may worsen if not treated promptly.
9. Pneumonia: The patient's chest x-ray shows evidence of pulmonary edema and/or pneumonia, which may worsen if not treated promptly.
10. Infection: The patient's elevated WBC count and lack of fever suggest possible infection, which may worsen if not treated promptly.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiogenic shock and adjust treatment as necessary.
2. Continue dialysis to treat acute renal failure and prevent worsening of kidney function.
3. Continue to treat hypotension with vasopressors and fluid resuscitation.
4. Monitor the patient's WBC count and consider treating sepsis with antibiotics if necessary.
5. Continue to treat respiratory failure with mechanical ventilation and oxygen therapy.
6. Monitor the patient's gastrointestinal symptoms and consider treating gastrointestinal bleeding if necessary.
7. Monitor the patient's potassium levels and consider treating hyperkalemia with potassium-binding agents if necessary.
8. Monitor the patient's lactate levels and consider treating metabolic acidosis with bicarbonate therapy if necessary.
9. Monitor the patient's chest x-ray and consider treating pneumonia with antibiotics if necessary.
10. Monitor the patient's infection and consider treating with antibiotics if necessary.

   80 yo woman with HTN HL CAD now s/p primary PCI to the mid-RCA for
   inferior STEMI.
   # MR: Has posterior pap muscle ischemia and severe MR but not a flail
   leaflet

   - Will continue IABP for better CO; 1:2 pulsations
   - Will continue to monitor and if gets worse may need MVR
   # Inferior STEMI: now s/p primary PCI to the mid-RCA.
   - CK peaked at 3000
   - continue aspirin 325, clopidogrel 75
   - cont home simvastatin 80
   - hold carvedilol, lisinopril given hypotension
   # Anemia, thrombocytopenia: bleeding vs hemolysis in setting of IABP.

   thought cardiogenic shock may be preload dependent given RCA infarct
   but UOP did not increase and had to increase dopa so may consider this
   to be systolic failure and may need to diurese for better CO. Renal saw
   and recommended UF. Intermittent v pacing resulting in disynchroinous
   IABP pulsation. Doing better with 1:2 IABP. Wil rececheck ECG today, if
   suinus then 1:1 for imptoved ABP and therefore potentiating better UF.
   - Cte IABP
   - hold off on anti-HTNs
   - Consider amio to keep in NSR for better forward flow with atrial
   kick.
   - Continue dopa
   - Continue UF
   - will ask EP to look at pacer since seems to have some irregular
   pacing spikes on telemetry and did not interrogate ppm yesterday
   # ARF: Likely secondary to two dye loads as well as poor CO
   - follow up renal recs re: CVVH
   - urine eos negative.
   #. Afib: new onset afib now s/p DCCV for hypotension
   - continue IV heparin
   - BB for rate control, will add amniodarone
   # HTN: hold amlodipine, BB, ACE as pt hypotensive
   #. COPD: cont home combivent

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 80-year-old woman who was admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of HTN, HL CAD, and s/p primary PCI to the mid-RCA for inferior STEMI. She has been experiencing cardiogenic shock, anemia, thrombocytopenia, and ARF. She is currently on mechanical ventilation and has been weaned off IABP with improved CO. She is also experiencing atrial fibrillation and has been treated with DCCV for hypotension.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.7C, heart rate of 80 bpm, and blood pressure of 98/38 mmHg. Her oxygen saturation is 96% on nasal cannula. Her respiratory support includes a 1L oxygen delivery device with a flow rate of 14 L/min.

The patient's physical examination reveals bilateral pitting edema, no stasis dermatitis, ulcers, scars, or xanthomas, and a soft, non-tender abdomen. Her neurological examination is normal.

Laboratory results show anemia, thrombocytopenia, and elevated WBC count. Her CK peaked at 3000, and she is being treated with aspirin, clopidogrel, and simvastatin. Her INR is 1.0, and her PT and PTT are 11.7 and 78.3 seconds, respectively.

The patient's medical history includes HTN, HL CAD, and hyperparathyroidism. She is being treated with various medications, including antihypertensives, antiplatelet agents, and statins.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Cardiogenic shock: The patient's cardiogenic shock may worsen if her CO does not improve, leading to further hypotension and decreased perfusion to vital organs.
2. Anemia and thrombocytopenia: The patient's anemia and thrombocytopenia may worsen if her bleeding continues, leading to further transfusion requirements and potential complications such as bleeding diathesis.
3. ARF: The patient's ARF may worsen if her CO does not improve, leading to further fluid accumulation and potential complications such as pulmonary edema and cardiac tamponade.
4. Atrial fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation may worsen if her rate control is not effective, leading to further hypotension and decreased perfusion to vital organs.
5. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension may worsen if her CO does not improve, leading to further decreased perfusion to vital organs and potential complications such as organ dysfunction and failure.

Based on the patient's current condition and potential complications, it is essential to continue monitoring her closely and adjusting her treatment plan as needed to prevent further complications and improve her outcome.

Summary:

The patient is an 80-year-old woman who underwent primary PCI for inferior STEMI and now presents with cardiogenic shock, atrial fibrillation, and acute respiratory failure. She is currently receiving IABP and UF therapy to improve cardiac output and reduce mitral regurgitation. Her blood pressure remains labile, and she requires dopamine to maintain adequate perfusion. She has also developed atrial fibrillation, which is being managed with IV heparin and beta-blockers.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiogenic Shock: The patient's cardiac output is compromised, and she requires ongoing IABP and UF therapy to improve perfusion. Further deterioration in cardiac function may lead to worsening shock and potential cardiac arrest.
2. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation may worsen her cardiac output and increase her risk of stroke. Anticoagulation therapy with IV heparin is necessary to prevent thromboembolic events.
3. Acute Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen her hypoxemia and hypercapnia, leading to further compromise of her cardiac function and increased risk of respiratory arrest.
4. Renal Failure: The patient's acute kidney injury may worsen her electrolyte imbalance and increase her risk of further complications, including cardiac arrhythmias and renal failure.
5. Sepsis: The patient's elevated white blood cell count and lack of fever may indicate an underlying septic process. Early recognition and treatment of sepsis are essential to prevent further deterioration in her condition.
6. Pulmonary Edema: The patient's pulmonary edema may worsen her respiratory failure and increase her risk of cardiac arrest.
7. Hyperparathyroidism: The patient's hyperparathyroidism may worsen her electrolyte imbalance and increase her risk of further complications, including cardiac arrhythmias and renal failure.
8. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension may worsen her cardiac output and increase her risk of further complications, including cardiac arrest.

   Assessment and Plan
   80 yo woman with HTN HL CAD now s/p primary PCI to the mid-RCA for
   inferior STEMI.
   # MR: Has posterior pap muscle ischemia and severe MR but not a flail
   leaflet
   - Will attempt to get volume off with UF to decrease MR
   - Will continue IABP for better CO; currently 1:2 pulsations
   - Will continue to monitor and if gets worse may need MVR
   # Inferior STEMI: now s/p primary PCI to the mid-RCA.
   - CK peaked at 3000
   - continue aspirin 325, clopidogrel 75
   - cont home simvastatin 80
   - hold carvedilol, lisinopril given hypotension
   # Anemia, thrombocytopenia: bleeding vs hemolysis in setting of IABP.
   Will check hemolysis panel, transfuse for HCT>30. Concern for HIT, will
   check PF4 AB.
   # Hypotension/shock: cardiogenic shock. Curtrently on UF with -1.5 lt
   yesterday. Intermittent v pacing resulting in disynchroinous IABP
   pulsation. Doing better with 1:2 IABP. Wil rececheck ECG today, if
   sinus then IABP at 1:1 for improved ABP and therefore potentiating
   better UF.
   - Cte IABP
   - hold off on anti-HTNs
   - Consider amio to keep in NSR for better forward flow with atrial
   kick.
   - Continue dopa
   - Continue UF
   - will ask EP to look at pacer since seems to have some irregular
   pacing spikes on telemetry and did not interrogate ppm yesterday
   # ARF: Likely secondary to two dye loads as well as poor CO
   - follow up renal recs re: CVVH
   - urine eos negative.
   #. Afib: new onset afib now s/p DCCV for hypotension
   - continue IV heparin
   - BB for rate control, will add amniodarone
   # HTN: hold amlodipine, BB, ACE as pt hypotensive
   #. COPD: cont home combivent
   #. Hyperparathyroidism: cont sensipar

   Nutrition:

   Chart reviewed.  Patient interviewed and examined on CCU Rounds with
   team.  I agree with Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **]
s H+P, A+P.  Cardiogenic shock due to IMI
   and apparent papillary muscle dysfunction with marked MR.  On IABP and
   dopamine.  Net negative > 1 liter with CVVH.  Plan is to continue
   negative fluid balance, IABP, and pressor support.  Will transfuse for
   HCT 21.  No CT to evaluate for RP bleed as she is too unstable to
   travel.  If HCT does not respond to transfusion, then will pursue CT.
   Hemolysis w/u.  Once fluid status better, will consider dobutamine to
   aid in IABP wean.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 80-year-old woman with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and coronary artery disease who presented with inferior STEMI and was treated with primary PCI to the mid-RCA. She has developed cardiogenic shock, atrial fibrillation, and acute renal failure.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Vital signs: T 36.5C, HR 80 bpm, BP 98/38 mmHg, RR 13 inspirations per minute, SpO2 96%.
* Hemodynamic monitoring: CVP 10 mmHg, PAP 47/21 mmHg, CO 4.2 L/min, CI 2.7 L/min/m2, mixed venous O2 saturation 48-59%.
* Fluid balance: Total in 3,288 mL, total out 4,730 mL, resulting in a negative balance of -1,442 mL.
* Respiratory support: Oxygen delivery device nasal cannula, SpO2 96%.
* Laboratory results:
	+ WBC 11.4 K/L
	+ Hct 23.7%
	+ Plt 84 K/L
	+ Cr 1.9 mg/dL
	+ TCO2 19 mmol/L
	+ Glucose 158 mg/dL
	+ Other labs: PT 11.7 seconds, PTT 78.3 seconds, INR 1.0, CK 2159 IU/L, CKMB 273 IU/L, Troponin-T 14.93 ng/mL, differential neutrophils 94.8%, lymphocytes 3.0%, monocytes 2.0%, eosinophils 0.1%, lactic acid 1.1 mmol/L, calcium 7.7 mg/dL, magnesium 2.2 mg/dL, phosphate 2.6 mg/dL

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Cardiogenic shock: The patient's cardiogenic shock is likely due to inferior STEMI and papillary muscle dysfunction with marked mitral regurgitation. If not managed appropriately, it can lead to further deterioration of cardiac function and potential mortality.
2. Atrial fibrillation: The patient's new-onset atrial fibrillation may lead to further hemodynamic instability, decreased cardiac output, and increased risk of stroke.
3. Acute renal failure: The patient's acute renal failure is likely secondary to cardiogenic shock and may require further management with continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT) or hemodialysis.
4. Bleeding: The patient's thrombocytopenia and anemia may increase the risk of bleeding, particularly in the setting of IABP and anticoagulation therapy.
5. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension may be due to cardiogenic shock, and if not managed appropriately, it can lead to further deterioration of cardiac function and potential mortality.
6. Hyperkalemia: The patient's elevated potassium levels may require further management with potassium-lowering agents.
7. Metabolic acidosis: The patient's lactic acidosis may require further management with bicarbonate therapy.

Based on the patient's current condition and potential complications, the following plan should be implemented:

1. Continue IABP and dopamine to support cardiac function.
2. Monitor and manage atrial fibrillation with rate control and anticoagulation therapy.
3. Continue CRRT or hemodialysis to manage acute renal failure.
4. Monitor and manage bleeding with platelet transfusions and anticoagulation therapy.
5. Monitor and manage hypotension with pressor support and fluid management.
6. Monitor and manage hyperkalemia with potassium-lowering agents.
7. Monitor and manage metabolic acidosis with bicarbonate therapy.
8. Consider dobutamine therapy to aid in IABP wean once fluid status improves.
9. Consider CT evaluation for RP bleed if HCT does not respond to transfusion.

   IABP pulsation.

   - hold off on anti-HTNs
   - Consider amio to keep in NSR for better forward flow with atrial
   kick.
   - Continue dopa
   - Continue UF
   - will ask EP to look at pacer since seems to have some irregular
   pacing spikes on telemetry and did not interrogate ppm yesterday
   # ARF: Likely secondary to two dye loads as well as poor CO
   - follow up renal recs re: CVVH
   - urine eos negative.
   #. Afib: new onset afib now s/p DCCV for hypotension
   - continue IV heparin

Summary:

The patient is an 80-year-old woman with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and coronary artery disease who presented with an inferior ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) and was treated with primary percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) to the mid-right coronary artery. She has since developed cardiogenic shock, atrial fibrillation, and acute respiratory failure. She is currently on mechanical ventilation, inotropic support, and dialysis.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiogenic Shock: The patient's cardiogenic shock is likely due to a combination of factors, including her underlying coronary artery disease, inferior STEMI, and possible septic shock. She is at risk for further deterioration and potential cardiac arrest if not managed promptly and effectively.
2. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient's new-onset atrial fibrillation is a significant concern, as it can lead to decreased cardiac output, increased risk of stroke, and potential cardiac arrhythmias. She requires close monitoring and management to maintain a stable heart rhythm.
3. Acute Respiratory Failure: The patient's acute respiratory failure is likely due to a combination of factors, including her underlying cardiopulmonary disease, sepsis, and possible pneumonia. She is at risk for further deterioration and potential respiratory arrest if not managed promptly and effectively.
4. Sepsis: The patient's elevated white blood cell count and possible septic shock suggest that she may be at risk for sepsis, which can lead to organ dysfunction and potential mortality.
5. Renal Failure: The patient's acute renal failure is likely due to a combination of factors, including her underlying cardiopulmonary disease, sepsis, and possible nephrotoxicity from contrast agents. She is at risk for further deterioration and potential renal failure if not managed promptly and effectively.
6. Hyperkalemia: The patient's elevated potassium levels suggest that she may be at risk for hyperkalemia, which can lead to cardiac arrhythmias and potential cardiac arrest.
7. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension is a significant concern, as it can lead to decreased cardiac output, organ dysfunction, and potential mortality. She requires close monitoring and management to maintain a stable blood pressure.
8. Pneumonia: The patient's possible pneumonia is a significant concern, as it can lead to further deterioration and potential respiratory failure if not managed promptly and effectively.
9. C Difficile: The patient's possible Clostridioides difficile infection is a significant concern, as it can lead to further deterioration and potential mortality if not managed promptly and effectively.

In conclusion, the patient is at high risk for multiple medical complications, including cardiogenic shock, atrial fibrillation, acute respiratory failure, sepsis, renal failure, hyperkalemia, hypotension, pneumonia, and C difficile infection. Close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent and treat these complications and ensure the patient's optimal care.

Summary:

The patient is an 80-year-old woman with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and coronary artery disease who presented with an inferior STEMI and underwent primary PCI to the mid-RCA. She has been admitted to the ICU for close monitoring and management. Her current condition is complicated by cardiogenic shock, atrial fibrillation, acute kidney injury, and possible septic shock.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.7C, heart rate of 80 bpm, and blood pressure of 98/38 mmHg. Her respiratory rate is 13 breaths per minute, and her oxygen saturation is 96% on nasal cannula oxygen. Her cardiac rhythm is paced atrial fibrillation, and her cardiac output is compromised.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated troponin-T levels, indicating ongoing myocardial injury. Her renal function is impaired, with a creatinine level of 1.9 mg/dL and an estimated glomerular filtration rate of 22 mL/min/1.73 m. Her white blood cell count is elevated, and her lactate level is low.

The patient's treatment plan includes ongoing IABP support, continuous IV heparin, and dopamine to maintain blood pressure. She is also receiving UF to decrease mitral regurgitation and improve cardiac output. The patient's code status is "do not resuscitate" if on ventilator for more than a few days and not improving.

Potential Medical Complications:

4. Septic shock: The patient's possible septic shock may worsen if not managed promptly and effectively, leading to further organ failure and potential mortality.
5. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen if not managed properly, leading to further respiratory compromise and potential mortality.
6. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis may worsen if not managed promptly and effectively, leading to further organ failure and potential mortality.

In conclusion, the patient is at risk for several potential medical complications, including cardiogenic shock, atrial fibrillation, acute kidney injury, septic shock, respiratory failure, and sepsis. Close monitoring and management are essential to prevent or mitigate these complications and improve the patient's outcomes.

She has a history of atrial fibrillation and is currently in atrial-paced rhythm. Her blood pressure is 98/38 mmHg, and her heart rate is 80 beats per minute.

The patient has a number of potential medical complications, including:

1. Cardiogenic shock: The patient's blood pressure is low, and she is receiving vasopressors to support her blood pressure. She also has a history of cardiogenic shock, which could worsen her condition.

8. Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD): The patient has a history of COPD, which could worsen her condition and increase her risk of death.

Overall, the patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management to prevent complications and improve her outcome.

Based on the provided medical progress note, I summarize the patient's condition as follows:

The patient is an 80-year-old woman who was admitted with a diagnosis of acute inferior STEMI, treated with primary PCI to the mid-RCA. She is currently in cardiogenic shock, receiving dopamine, IABP, and UF. Her hemodynamic status is unstable, with a rising PAd and decreasing CI. She has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and hyperparathyroidism.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Hemoglobin: 9.9 g/dL
* Platelet count: 69 K/uL
* Creatinine: 1.4 mg/dL
* Lactic acid: 1.1 mmol/L
* Albumin: 2.6 g/dL
* LDH: 1540 IU/L
* Calcium: 8.8 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.3 mg/dL
* Phosphate: 3.1 mg/dL

The patient is receiving several medications, including:

* Dopamine
* Argatroban
* Aspirin
* Clopidogrel
* Simvastatin
* Amiodarone
* Sensipar
* Combivent

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continuing IABP to maintain pressure for UF
* Attempting to wean dopamine
* Weaning IABP once PAd is at an acceptable range
* Repeating Echo today
* Monitoring for worsening condition and potential need for MVR
* Continuing CVVH for volume removal

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

* Hemolytic anemia due to IABP-induced hemolysis
* Bleeding complications due to anticoagulation therapy
* Renal failure due to contrast-induced nephropathy and poor forward flow
* Respiratory failure due to cardiogenic shock and COPD
* Sepsis due to VAP
* Cardiac arrhythmias due to atrial fibrillation
* Hypocalcemia due to hypoparathyroidism
* Hyperkalemia due to potassium imbalance

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust her treatment plan accordingly to prevent or manage these potential complications.

Summary:

The patient is an 80-year-old woman with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and coronary artery disease (CAD) who presented with an inferior ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) and was treated with primary percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) to the mid-right coronary artery (RCA). She is currently in cardiogenic shock and is being treated with dopamine, intra-aortic balloon pump (IABP), and ultrafiltration (UF). Her platelet count is low, and she has been diagnosed with hemolysis, which is likely caused by the IABP. She also has anemia, which is being treated with 2 units of packed red blood cells (pRBCs). Her blood chemistry results show elevated levels of lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), creatine kinase (CK), and troponin-T, indicating myocardial damage.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiogenic shock: The patient's cardiogenic shock is likely to persist, and she may require further interventions, such as mechanical circulatory support or cardiac transplantation.
2. Hemolysis: The patient's hemolysis is likely to continue, and she may require further transfusions to manage her anemia.
3. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia is likely to persist, and she may require further platelet transfusions to manage her bleeding risk.
4. Acute kidney injury (AKI): The patient's AKI is likely to persist, and she may require further dialysis to manage her electrolyte imbalance.
5. Atrial fibrillation (AFib): The patient's AFib is likely to persist, and she may require further anticoagulation therapy to manage her risk of stroke.
6. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely to persist, and she may require further respiratory support, such as mechanical ventilation.
7. Infection: The patient is at risk of developing an infection, particularly pneumonia, given her prolonged hospitalization and immunosuppression.
8. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient is at risk of developing gastrointestinal bleeding, particularly in the setting of her hemolysis and thrombocytopenia.
9. Renal failure: The patient's renal failure is likely to persist, and she may require further dialysis to manage her electrolyte imbalance.
10. Cardiac tamponade: The patient's cardiac tamponade is a potential complication of her cardiogenic shock and may require further interventions, such as pericardiocentesis or cardiac surgery.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiogenic shock and adjust her treatment accordingly.
2. Continue to monitor the patient's hemolysis and anemia, and adjust her transfusion therapy accordingly.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's thrombocytopenia and adjust her platelet transfusion therapy accordingly.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's AKI and adjust her dialysis therapy accordingly.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's AFib and adjust her anticoagulation therapy accordingly.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory failure and adjust her respiratory support accordingly.
7. Continue to monitor the patient for signs of infection and take appropriate measures to prevent and treat infections.
8. Continue to monitor the patient for signs of gastrointestinal bleeding and take appropriate measures to prevent and treat bleeding.
9. Continue to monitor the patient for signs of renal failure and adjust her dialysis therapy accordingly.
10. Consider referring the patient to a cardiologist for further evaluation and management of her cardiac condition.

   check PF4 AB.

   yesterday. Intermittent v pacing resulting in disynchroinous IABP
   pulsation. Doing better with 1:2 IABP. Wil rececheck ECG today, if
   sinus then IABP at 1:1 for improved ABP and therefore potentiating
   better UF.
   - Cte IABP
   - hold off on anti-HTNs
   - Consider amio to keep in NSR for better forward flow with atrial
   kick.
   - Continue dopa
   - Continue UF
   - will ask EP to look at pacer since seems to have some irregular
   pacing spikes on telemetry and did not interrogate ppm yesterday
   # ARF: Likely secondary to two dye loads as well as poor CO
   - follow up renal recs re: CVVH
   - urine eos negative.
   #. Afib: new onset afib now s/p DCCV for hypotension
   - continue IV heparin

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 80-year-old woman who was admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of inferior STEMI and underwent primary PCI to the mid-RCA. She has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and coronary artery disease.

The patient's vital signs are as follows:

* Temperature: 98.1F (36.7C)
* Heart rate: 80-89 bpm
* Blood pressure: 106/38 mmHg (71/30-137/55 mmHg)
* Respiratory rate: 18 inspirations per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 97%
* Heart rhythm: Atrial flutter

The patient has several medical complications, including:

* Anemia and thrombocytopenia, which may be due to bleeding or hemolysis in the setting of intra-aortic balloon pump (IABP)
* Hypotension and shock, which may be cardiogenic in origin
* Acute renal failure (ARF), which may be secondary to two dye loads and poor cardiac output
* Atrial fibrillation, which was newly diagnosed and treated with DCCV
* Hyperparathyroidism, which is being managed with Sensipar

The patient is receiving several medications, including:

* Aspirin 325 mg
* Clopidogrel 75 mg
* Simvastatin 80 mg
* Dopamine
* Calcium gluconate
* Argatroban
* Heparin
* Amiodarone
* Sensipar

The patient is also receiving several therapies, including:

* IABP
* UF (ultrafiltration)
* CRRT (continuous renal replacement therapy)
* Dialysis
* Stress ulcer prophylaxis
* DVT prophylaxis
* VAP prophylaxis

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Continued bleeding or hemolysis due to IABP
* Worsening of anemia and thrombocytopenia
* Decreased cardiac output and worsening of hypotension
* Progression of ARF
* Development of sepsis or other infections
* Further cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias or cardiac arrest.

Based on the patient's 24-hour progress note, here is a summary of the information and potential medical complications:

**Patient's Condition:**

* The patient is an elderly female with a history of anemia, ineffective coping, impaired skin integrity, acute renal failure, and acute myocardial infarction (STEMI).
* She is currently in the ICU, receiving multiple medications and interventions.

**Vital Signs:**

* Temperature: 36.7C (98.1F)
* Heart rate: 80 bpm
* Blood pressure: 106/38 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 18 breaths/min
* Oxygen saturation: 97%

**Hemodynamic Monitoring:**

* Central venous pressure (CVP): 26 mmHg
* Pulmonary artery pressure (PAP): 62/31 mmHg
* Cardiac output (CO): 2.9 L/min
* Cardiac index (CI): 1.8 L/min/m2
* Mixed venous oxygen saturation: 44-46%

**Fluid Balance:**

* Total input: 4,549 mL
* Total output: 6,575 mL
* Balance: -2,026 mL

**Labs:**

* Hemoglobin (Hb): 9.9 g/dL
* Platelet count (Plt): 69 K/uL
* White blood cell count (WBC): 13.3 K/uL
* Creatinine (Cr): 1.4 mg/dL
* Glucose: 112 mg/dL
* Troponin-T: 14.93 ng/mL
* Lactic acid: 1.1 mmol/L
* Albumin: 2.6 g/dL
* LDH: 1540 IU/L

**Potential Medical Complications:**

* Bleeding complications due to platelet count of 69 K/uL and the use of anticoagulants (lepirudin, argatroban).
* Renal failure, which may worsen due to the patient's pre-existing condition and the use of nephrotoxic medications.
* Myocardial infarction, which may progress to heart failure or arrhythmias.
* Respiratory failure, which may worsen due to the patient's underlying pulmonary disease and the use of mechanical ventilation.
* Sepsis, which may develop due to the patient's compromised immune system and the presence of indwelling catheters.
* Infection, which may develop due to the patient's compromised immune system and the presence of indwelling catheters.
* Malnutrition, which may worsen due to the patient's underlying condition and the use of parenteral nutrition.

**Plan:**

* Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs, hemodynamic status, and laboratory results.
* Adjust the patient's fluid management and medication regimen as necessary.
* Consider consulting with a nephrologist to optimize the patient's renal care.
* Consider consulting with a cardiologist to optimize the patient's cardiac care.
* Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust the patient's ventilator settings as necessary.
* Consider consulting with an infectious disease specialist to optimize the patient's antimicrobial therapy.
* Consider consulting with a nutritionist to optimize the patient's nutritional care.

   Assessment and Plan
   80 yo woman with HTN HL CAD now s/p primary PCI to the mid-RCA for
   inferior STEMI.
   # MR/Shock: Has posterior pap muscle ischemia and severe MR but not a
   flail leaflet. Currenltly in cardiogenic shock; treated with dopamine,
   IABP, and UF. Overall -3.5 lt yesterday. PAd was improving through the
   day (as low as17) but rose this morning. The validity of this rise is
   questionable since CI improved during the same time frame, and if PAd
   was truly elevated this would cause decrease in CI.
   - Plan is to continue IABP to maintain pressure for UF. Once PAd at
   acceptable range ~10, then wean IABP.
   - amiodarone to keep atrial pacing going
   - Attempt to wean dopamine
   - If can wean dopamine, may be able to wean IABP
   - Plan for surgery at some point
   - Repeat Echo today
   - Will continue to monitor and if gets worse may need MVR
   - continue CVVH for volume removal
   # Inferior STEMI: now s/p primary PCI to the mid-RCA.
   - CK peaked at 3000
   - continue aspirin 325, clopidogrel 75
   - cont home simvastatin 80
   - hold carvedilol, lisinopril given hypotension
   # Anemia: Hemolysis unlikely given normal hapto and t bili. On my read
   PBS only occasional schistos. Rectal
 for hemocult. S/P 2pRBCs with
   appropriate post transfusion response. Despite the lack of strongly
   positive hemolysis [**Last Name (LF) **], [**First Name3 (LF) 3468**] caused by IABP is still strongly
   supported by history. Will continue to monitor. If cont to drop with
   scan for RP bleed.
   # TCP: most likely IABP induced. However HIT is very likely. Sent HIT
   and transitioned to argatroban. Plan is that if plt rise with this
   change, then most likely HIT and would cont argatroban; if platelets
   cont to drop and [**First Name11 (Name Pattern1) **]
[**Initial (NamePattern1) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) **], then IABP-cause and then would go back to
   heparin.
   # ARF: Contrast induced and poor forward flow. Improving on UF.
   - follow up renal recs re: CVVH
   - urine eos negative.
   #. Afib: new onset afib now s/p DCCV for hypotension
   - continue argatroban
   - BB for rate control, will add amniodarone
   # COPD: cont home combivent
   # Hyperparathyroidism: cont sensipar
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:  consider tube feeds?
